crypto.name: Somkracht 65537
crypto.desc:
Is this how RSA works? I read something about p and q somewhere.

This challenge is provided by Challenge The Cyber.

crypto.name: Substitute Teacher
crypto.desc: We had this substitute teacher who always bragged that he was a good writer. We found a story he wrote, but it is just all gibberish.

forensic.name: BitLocked
forensic.desc: I found this old encrypted SD-Card, but I forgot the password. Luckily I always make a photo to know which recovery key belongs to which device. Can you check what is on the disk?

forensic.name: Painted Black
forensic.desc: The Ravenbook Police Department is using a new product to black out Personally identifiable information (PII) from their Word documents before making them public. We heard through the grapevine that this product is not that safe. Can you check this document and retrieve the blacked out information?

forensic.name: The Wizard
forensic.desc: After some issues involving a robe and wizard hat, HR decided it is was best if we let go of this old developer we had. However with him gone we now lost access to some systems, since he had his own way of saving passwords. Can you help us out?

forensic.name: ToShredsYouSay
forensic.desc:
I bought a new shredder and I just tested it. I think it does a decent job, I made a scan of the results, what do you think?

Besides doing this challenge digitally it is also possible to pick up the shredded papers in the CTF tent.

misc.name: ColoredBlocks
misc.desc: I saw some weird code-blocks on the ground of Amsterdam Central Station, I think they are part of a system for blind and visually impaired travelers. I tried to make some of these code-blocks in the colors of WHY2025, can you decode them?

misc.name: Just One Line
misc.desc:
What would a CTF be without a perl one-liner:
$ echo ${FLAG} | perl -ple '$n=()=/./g;$_=~s/./$|--?ord($&)%$n:ord($&)-$^F**5/eg'

misc.name: TZe 611
misc.desc: I've captured this weird transmission. Can you make any sense of it?

misc.name: TitleCase
misc.desc:
A modern rerun of a SHA2017 challenge...

It was based on a real-life bug where the developers used this technique to turn a string containing "true" into a Python boolean:
with urllib.request.urlopen("<ATTACKER CONTROLLED>") as f:
   api_response = json.loads(f.read())
   boolean_value = eval(api_response["some_field"].title())

net.name: Captcha 2.0
net.desc: Someone hacked our MCH challenge Captcha, luckily we still have the network logs.

net.name: Ransomware attack
net.desc: Our company was attacked with ransomware. All of our files were encrypted. Luckily we could get most of those files back from backups, but an important file is still encrypted. We found some information in our network logs. Can you help to get this file back?

net.name: enlightenment
net.desc:
My lights have been acting weird lately. Can you shed some light on what's going on?
ZigBee network key: d73581c3485ff294a9c70b840203fcc7

onsite.name: Badge Crackme
onsite.desc: We found an ELF file you run on your shiny new WHY2025 badge. Can you figure out the password and get the flag?

onsite.name: Terminal Error onsite
onsite.desc:
Inspired by this fantastic movie scene.

This is the onsite version of this challenge, there is also an online variant. We have two Game Boys in the tent. One will run the challenge while the other contains a flash card on which you can flash your exploit! Note that you will need to exfiltrate the flag from the target Gameboy. You can best use the BGB emulator for testing. Visit the CTF tent to run your exploit on the real Gameboy.

onsite.name: Wemos
onsite.desc:
I found this old microcontroller board, but I have no idea what it does anymore. It also might be missing a 'shield'. Could you investigate it?
The board for this challenge is available in the CTF tent, as well as some equipment you could use for the analysis.

pwn.name: Job Security
pwn.desc: With this new COBOL frontend for GCC 15 I am guaranteed a job for the next 50 years!

pwn.name: Old Memes Never Die
pwn.desc: Always want to do a bufferoverflow? Here is your chance! Ideal for first timers, you even get the source code!

pwn.name: Terminal Error online
pwn.desc:
Inspired by this fantastic movie scene.

This is the online variant of this challenge, we also have an onsite variant with two real Game Boys. We use the BGB emulator.

rev.name: 3 Ball Mark
rev.desc: Can you pick the right ball out Mark his magic bag ten times in a row?

rev.name: Gamerboy
rev.desc:
A nice game for enthusiasts.

This challenge is provided by Challenge The Cyber.

rev.name: Hacker Event DB
rev.desc: Binary sleuth, we need your help! We recently developed a new data format for keeping track of all the quadrennial Dutch hacker conventions. Our interns have painstakingly filled this database; you can list its contents by doing `./hedb hacker_events.bin`. When we checked our internal repository the other day a new database file called `haxx0r_sc3ntz.bin` appeared out of nowhere. It is much larger in size and doesn't seem to exhibit benign behavior. Can you figure out what the hell is going on here?

rev.name: Keypad
rev.desc:
I have been playing with a safe lock and a logic analyzer for a while. But I forgot which buttons I pressed, could you take a look?
Note: There are no brackets on the keypad, but you will figure out where they go, won't you?

rev.name: Lazy Code 1.0
rev.desc: This code is so lazy it takes ages to run. Can you fix it so it runs faster?

rev.name: Lazy Code 2.0
rev.desc: This code is so lazy it takes ages to run. Can you fix it so it runs faster?

rev.name: Zen Master
rev.desc: We're developing a new CPU, can you help beta test it?

rev.name: aSYMMETRICK
rev.desc: Find the key for user WHYCTF and Submit the flag by doing flag{md5(key)}

web.name: Flyer
web.desc: To promote the WHY2025 event we created a generator to create your own WHY2025 flyer!
